description:
1610s, from French déclivité, from Latin declivitatem, dēclīvitās,
from dēclivis (“a sloping downward”), from de (“down”) + clīvus (“a slope”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱleywo-, from Proto-Indo-European *ḱley- (“to lean”) (English lean).

entries.meaning: (geomorphology) The downward slope of a hill; the downward slope of a curve.
examples: The velocity of flowing waters is very far from being in proportion to the quantity of declivity in their bed: […] .

entries.meaning: A downward bend in a path.
(entomology) An inward curve of the exoskeleton of an insect, such as between body segments; a segment of an insect's body where the exoskeleton curves inward.
examples: Males of all species have more developed armature of the elytral declivity than females (Figs. S, 6, 8, 9, 11-14).
